body:
FreeBSD probably does not support inotify and because of that our config file watcher relies on manually polling the file for changes.

I think the only solution is to disable the live config reload in the config. That should help. I'm not aware of an inotify alternative on FreeBSD.

I'll try to see if I can patch this in my FreeBSD VM, thanks for trying anyways. Though that means it likely will not be fixed for a while.

Disabling live config reload does the job though, right?
I can confirm, when starting like this `alacritty --no-live-config-reload` there is no load according to htop.

There's also a configuration file option if you don't wish to add the command line parameter. Though the best solution would obviously be to actually support this properly on BSD, even if only with an inotify dependency.

It appears that I am running into this on OpenBSD.

I am curious -- what is inotify used for? Watching the config file?
I can also confirm that `--no-live-config-reload` causes there to be no idle CPU usage. Before it was ~20%.

> I am curious -- what is inotify used for? Watching the config file?

Correct, which is why `--no-live-config-reload` will fix it (there's also a configuration file option for that).

issue.title: Add inotify support on BSD

labels.name: Z-needs implementation
labels.description: Needs an implementation, will accept PRs

repository.name: notify
repository.description: Cross-platform filesystem notification library for Rust.

issue.body:
So a while back someone reported the following issue to Alacritty: https://github.com/alacritty/alacritty/issues/3871

This isn't much of a surprise, it looks like notify's BSD implementation is just using the worst, most general fallback which causes high system load due to a relatively high poll rate set by Alacritty.

But it seems like at least some BSDs do have the ability to support inotify and might potentially have other native APIs too (I'm not familiar with those at least). I'm curious if this has been investigated, I'd assume that BSD just has not been a priority?

body:
Since I haven't gotten around to fixing this in notify for a while now, I've decided to at the very least open an issue: https://github.com/notify-rs/notify/issues/273.

I think a good short-term solution might be to just increase the poll time in Alacritty, since that should only affect systems that require manual polling. That way you might need to wait a second or two until your config file updates, but you still have live config reload and you don't kill your CPU.

issue.title: Increase file watcher delay on BSD
issue.body:
Since BSD does not support inotify polling in the `notify` crate and
instead relies on manual filesystem polling, this would cause a high CPU
usage at 100 polls a second.

A separate polling rate of once per second is now used for platforms
which do not support filesystem polling, allowing users to still make
use of live config reload on BSD.

Fixes #3871.
